Award.AwardTitle: CLICK: Color and Light to Improve Chemical Knowledge

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
CLICK: Color and Light to Improve Chemical Knowledge

A significant obstacle to engaging undergraduate students enrolled in chemistry courses is transcending the artificial boundaries separating lecture and laboratory activities and students' everyday experiences. This project, known as CLICK (Color and Light to Improve Chemical Knowledge), will provide students with multiple opportunities to explore connections between everyday life experiences and subject matter learned formally in chemistry courses throughout the undergraduate curriculum. Students will advance their experiential learning by engaging in various integrated sequential activities that progress through levels of complexity, from (1) using smartphone cameras and hand-held UV lamps to explore fluorescent and phosphorescent properties of common household materials; to (2) employing portable multifunctional chemical analysis systems to design their own experiments for investigating their daily surroundings; to (3) performing more refined and sophisticated laboratory-based experimentation with materials students bring in from outside the laboratory.

Outreach and dissemination activities will include: sharing CLICK activities with colleagues during faculty development workshops; involving the SUNY Oneonta Noyce scholars in informal science education activities at the campus Science Discovery Center; presenting at regional and national meetings; and publishing in appropriate journals. A variety of assessment and evaluation methods will be employed to measure the impact of the strategies and pedagogy developed by the project. These include the Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire (MSLQ), the Chemistry Expectations Survey (CHEMX), the Views of the Nature of Science (VNOS) questionnaire, and American Chemical Society standardized exams, in addition to locally developed techniques to determine student engagement and learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of CLICK was to adapt and develop experiments that exploit interesting effects caused by interactions between light and matter, such as fluorescence and photochromism, to improve engagement and learning at various levels in the undergraduate chemistry curriculum. 

Starting with General Chemistry II, we adapted a fluorescent clock reaction using household chemicals (laundry detergent, hydrogen peroxide, Vitamin C, tincture of iodine, and vinegar) and had students analyze the effect of changing the amounts of the various ingredients individually and timing how long it took for the fluorescence to quench, or turn off,  (Figure 1) to ultimately determine a rate law for the overall chemical reaction. 

For Organic Chemistry I, we further developed an existing green synthesis project for a class of compounds that includes members known to be useful as precursors for blockbuster chemotherapy and blood pressure drugs, as well as members known to change colors and/or fluoresce when interacting with metal ions. Each student made a different compound (about 150 different compounds overall).  Compounds were evaluated by standard organic analytical techniques but were also qualitatively evaluated for fluorescence, photochromism (change of color when exposed to light), thermochromism (change of color when exposed to a temperature change), and their ability to sense metal ions. Examples of photochromism and fluorescent detection of metal ions with a variety of compounds are shown in Figure 2.

For Organic Chemistry II, we created a new green chemistry project for making more than a dozen different members of a class of compounds known to be medicinally active against various microbes. The compounds also inhibit the enzyme responsible for browning in fruits and vegetables, so we also created a novel bioassay to test the effectiveness of the compounds in the organic lab by testing their ability to inhibit browning in a variety of fruits and vegetables during a single lab period. Selectivity was also evaluated by assessing the activity of another enzyme once the browning assay was complete (Figure 3). These compounds were later evaluated by Biochemistry I students using quantitative biochemical techniques to determine specific activity the following semester in a collaborative project.

For Analytical Chemistry, we developed an interdisciplinary experiment where students explored the ability of compounds previously synthesized could detect infinitesimal quantities of toxins such as cyanide ion using color changes when the compounds and toxins interacted (Figure 4), reminiscent of the metal ion assay from Organic Chemistry II but using much more rigorous techniques and analyses. The compounds potentially could be synthesized as part of an inorganic chemistry laboratory course.

In Physical Chemistry I, students used Vernier equipment to investigate the kinetics of UV-color changing beads. These beads are commercial beads that children use to make jewelry. These beads are white when exposed to normal light, but temporarily change color such as red, purple, blue, etc. when exposed to 400 nm UV light (Figure 5). The color of the bead slowly changes back to white over a period of minutes and the rate varies depending on the color of the bead.

In Physical Chemistry II, students investigated the visible spectrum of three different light bulbs: incandescent, light emitted diode (LED), and compact fluorescent (CF) using portable Vernier devices to measure their spectra. Students fit each spectrum to a formula, determined the color temperature (what color the light appears), and compared their experimental results to the values printed on the packages. They then recorded the spectra of three different light bulbs from around the area to see if they could determine the type of light source. An example of one recording is shown in Figure 6.  

The PIs organized a well-attended symposium for the American Chemical Society in 2018 entitled ?Using Light, Color, & Spectroscopy to Increase Student Engagement in the Laboratory? where we each presented recent project results. 

Undergraduate researchers assisted the PIs throughout the project as we developed new experiments and disseminated results at national American Chemical Society meetings: 11 oral and 18 poster presentations. Of the 20 undergraduates who participated in the development of the laboratory experiments, 11 went directly to graduate programs in chemistry, 4 went on to health programs (2 medical school, 1 pharmacy school, and 1 dental school), and 4 went directly into careers in industry.
